displayed_text: Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that. Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. We have to use the generic name. The, the drug company, they want the one that they want -- the fancy name. Um. So (Pause) Patient: Well, uh, the gentleman, M_, said he had one more chemo for me, but he didn’t have much faith it would do anything. So, maybe it was the same. Doctor: Well, it is – you never know until you try. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: And this is a – when we look through all the things about what could you do that’s different in here, uh, we have this clinical study – Patient: Oh. Doctor: - and the first thing that we had to check is you had to be ARV seven expressing. Patient: That was so Doctor: So you are ARV seven positive. Patient: Ah.

Doctor: Okay? Because again, you are sort of, your tongue’s sort of moving over, but your brain looks good. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: But if it gets worse, it don’t make sense, I’d go back to the ER because I don’t know, because that’s what I would say, and it looks like your tongue’s a little bit more trouble getting over, huh, than the last time. Patient: Okay. I mean, these sometime it’s off and on. Sometimes I can you know- Doctor: Well, when you get tired it can do it. Patient: Yeah. So. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Good. Patient: Thank you, doc. Doctor: Okay. Hang in there. Don’t forget your patch. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses.

Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors. Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. I’ll just give you my funny story because my patient when we first started, he was like number one or two and no one was travelling, right, he was like no, I’m not gonna travel. So, now I’m at home and it’s Sunday night and all the sudden my cellphone rings but it’s like nine p.m. and I’m like boy, that’s odd, who would be calling me. Not a number I recognize so I was like uh, do I pick it up, it’s probably a telemarketer, ah, okay. So, I picked it up and it was some guy he was is this Dr. H____? I’m like well, it depends, who wants to know.

Patient: Yeah I Doctor: Where were you now? Patient: I was down in Kentucky. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhmm. Sometimes I have to travel for the job. Doctor: That’s good. Was it hot? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal. Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits. Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different.

Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, uh, they’ll just tell you what to worry about, what not to worry about, what fevers we worry about, what numbers to call, uh, what you can eat, what you don’t eat sometimes. I don’t know what the class really is about. Patient: Okay. Family Member: So, S_ had, um, he was getting chemo, he had a bathroom that nobody was supposed to use. Doctor: They’ll talk to you about that and teach it in the class, but I don’t think that’s an issue. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: and will continue to. I know G___ asked you a lot about that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: He wrote three pads and… So do you want to see Dr. F__? Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean… Doctor: Yeah it’s okay with me. Family Member: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Uh huh, Yeah I think he’s excellent. I haven’t talked to him in a long time, but he and I are close. We used to talk all the time. Family Member: Okay. Gives you a good reason for you to get back together (Laughs) Doctor: M____. Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there.

Patient: I was gonna say something oh that uh you know I had – I got some sleeping pills from a friend of mine. He’s a former nurse- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -okay so he done retired and stuff, but he gave me two sleeping pills that I took – and please believe me, I took with my OxyContin pill. I was like here – y’all just don’t know. I was feeling so good because the OxyContin was making me feel good, then I took a sleeping pill, I went right on to sleep. I slept the whole night. I didn’t wake up until the next morning. When I got out of bed this morning, I felt so good. Doctor: So did you ask him the name? Patient: Um ro-ro-roe or ro something like that, but it was – it – I mean I feel so good. I slept through the whole night. Doctor: Restoril, Restoril is a pill is a sleeping pill. Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do?

Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia? Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. Not in everybody, but usually I see it more in younger guys like you than I do in, you know, much older guys. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, but I think that would be the easiest thing to do. It’s a pill you take every day. I have a range of responses. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: ‘Cuz – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Don’t – Patient: And I can just – Doctor: Don’t aggravate! Patient: Tell the difference. I can tell the difference. Doctor: Oh, yeah. And we know you’re okay now ‘cuz we know when you’re not okay because it’s not subtle. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: When you’re not okay, you’re just being – peeing gobs of blood, tissue – we know you’re not okay. That’s not happening right now. So, we’re at this perfect window – Patient: Right. Doctor: Where we gotta make a decision – Patient: So okay, doc. So, let me --

Family Member: The other girl said something about time releases you can’t cut in half, but I don’t think those … Doctor: Yeah. These are just regular Motrins. Family Member: Not taking more than we have to so we’ve been taking the two hundreds. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah no I like that. In fact if you can keep it lower that’s even better. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Just what we need. Patient: Yeah as little as possible. Doctor: Yeah, so I looked at all the other stuff that your doctor wanted and you know all of that is fine unless we put you on something else if we decide to go with any treatment then Patient: It would have to be approved through, yeah. Doctor: we may have to take a relook and… Family Member: That’s why we made you the copies…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 10 years (5 years but le: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 10 years (5 years but less than 10 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)
